_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Classroom training includes ammonia awareness and safety.  On the job includes training on operating procedures.
_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Classroom training includes a written test.  Operating procedures include demonstration and observation.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) covered process elements for the Storage & Handling of anhydrous ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Maintenance, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. Equipment associated with this covered process may eventually include three 30,000-gallon stationary storage tanks, ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.  (There is only one tank currently present at the Facility).  From the stationary storage tanks, the anhydrous ammonia is either transferred to the 10-34-0 fertilizer manufacturing process, or to nurse tanks.  The Huntington Facility is responsible for the transfer of anhydrous ammonia and for the operations of the stationary pipe reactor in accordance with the PSM/RMPr.  



Anhydrous ammonia may be transported to the Facility by a 9,000-gallon commercial tanker truck.  The commercial tanker truck (Vendor) Operator will transfer the anhydrous ammonia from its tanker truck to the storage tanks.  The vendor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation. At a minimum, the vendor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan to its vendor for review and a copy of its PSM/RMPr Document upon request.

_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Classroom training for ammonia awareness and safety.  On the job training for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_3.CT_OtherType: Written test for classroom training.  Demonstration and observation testing for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_3.Description: The Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) covered process elements for the 10-34-0 manufacturing process at this Facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Maintenance, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. Equipment associated with this covered process includes a stationary pipe reactor that is owned and operated by the Facility.   Trained Helena Facility Process Operators transfer the anhydrous ammonia from the stationary storage tanks and to its stationary pipe reactor to manufacture 10-34-0 Fertilizer.  The Huntington Facility is responsible for the transfer of anhydrous ammonia and for the operations of the stationary pipe reactor in accordance with the PSM/RMPr.

_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Emergency shutt-off switch to liquid pump
_prev_prog_2.TR_OtherType: Classroom training for ammonia awareness and safety.  On the job for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_2.CT_OtherType: Written test for classroom training.  Demonstration and observation for Operating Procedures.
_prev_prog_2.Description: The Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) covered process elements for the micronutrient formulation process at this Facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed.  This is a Program Level 2 process because the aqua ammonia concentration is less than 44% by weight and it is not connected to the anhydrous ammonia processes; thus, the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rule which makes the RMP Program 3 requirements not applicable.  Nevertheless, for the sake of consistency the PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Maintenance, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. Equipment associated with this covered process includes multiple fertilizer blenders that are owned and operated by the Facility and ancillary piping, valves, and process control equipment.  Trained Helena Facility Process Operators transfer the aqua ammonia from the stationary storage tank to the blenders to make various types of fertilizer products.  The Huntington Facility is responsible for the transfer of aqua ammonia and for the operations of the blenders in accordance with the PSM/RMPr.

_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Branch Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) covered process elements for the Storage & Handling of aqua ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. This is a Program Level 2 process because the aqua ammonia concentration is less than 44% by weight and it is not connected to the anhydrous ammonia processes; thus, the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rule which makes the RMP Program 3 requirements not applicable.  Nevertheless, for the sake of consistency the PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Maintenance, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. Equipment associated with this covered process includes a single 30,000-gallon stationary storage tanks, ancillary pumps, piping, and valves.   



Aqua ammonia may be transported to the Facility by a 5,000-gallon commercial tanker truck.  The commercial tanker truck (Vendor) Operator will transfer the anhydrous ammonia from its tanker truck to the storage tanks.  The vendor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation, maintenance, and training procedures and documentation. At a minimum, the vendor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan to its vendor for review and a copy of its PSM/RMPr Document upon request.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program document (PSM/RMPr) was prepared on behalf of Helena Chemical Company (Helena) pursuant to the requirements of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r) as codified by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) at 29 CFR ? 1910.119 and by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68.  The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to one or more Branch in Huntington, IN.  At this Facility, Helena engages in the formulation, distribution and sale of fertilizers, most of who use Helena's products to support agricultural Branch (See Section 3.0).  



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from the Huntington Facility located approximately 1.75 miles east-northeast of Huntington at 104 Beaty Drive, Huntington, IN 46750.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Huntington Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Huntington Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release (even though a release is unlikely) will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena is deleting the railcar storage process in the current RMP and adding 2 aqua ammonia processes.



FACILITY



The Huntington, IN Facility operates fertilizer blending and distribution equipment at its Facility and sells fertilizer products to farms and other distributors.  The Huntington Facility intends to operate the following four covered processes:

    

Process 1:  Anhydrous Ammonia Storage and Handling.  Anhydrous ammonia is primarily off-loaded from 9,000-gallon commercial tanker trucks and into a 30,000-gallon stationary storage tank.  The Facility currently has only one 30,000-gallon storage tank but plans to construct up to two more 30,000-gallon storage tanks at

a future date.  The transfer Branch from the tanker truck to the storage tank(s) is conducted by the commercial truck operator (Contractor/Vendor).  Once in the storage tank, Branch personnel manage the anhydrous ammonia.  The anhydrous ammonia is then transferred to either the 10-34-0 Reacting process or to nurse tanks.  (This Facility does not own or operate nurse tanks.  However, other Helena Chemical Company retail Branch that are located close to Huntington, IN transport their nurse tanks to the Huntington, IN Facility, fill the nurse tanks, and sell the anhydrous ammonia in the nurse tank to the end user [e.g. Farmer].)  The transfer of anhydrous ammonia to the 10-34-0 manufacturing process or to the nurse tanks is conducted by Facility Process Operators from Huntington or HCC personnel from the nearby Facility, in accordance with the PSM/RMPr accident prevention program.  



Process 2:  10-34-0 Manufacturing.  The facility will manufacture liquid ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer (i.e. 10-34-0 Fertilizer) using a Stationary Pipe Reactor (SPR).  The ammonium polyphosphate fertilizer is manufactured by blending anhydrous ammonia with phosphoric acid in the SPR.  The resulting ammonium polyphosphate solution is blended with water and discharged to a "wet well." Once in the wet well, the product is cooled in a packed tower heat exchanger.  The product is then further cooled in a non-contact heat exchanger while at the same time vaporizing the liquid ammonia that is an input to the SPR.  The anhydrous ammonia used in the process may will be stored in the stationary storage tank (see Process 1). Trained Process Operators operate and maintain the SPR in accordance with the PSM/RMPr accident prevention program.  



Process 3:  Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling.  Aqua ammonia is primarily off-loaded from 9,000-gallon commercial tanker trucks and into a 30,000-gallon stationary storage tank by the commercial truck operator (Contractor/Vendor).  The Facility currently

has only one 30,000-gallon storage tank.    Once in the storage tank, Branch personnel manage the aqua ammonia.  The aqua-ammonia is then transferred to two blenders to make fertilizer micronutrients.  The transfer of aqua ammonia to the micronutrient formulation process is conducted by Facility Process Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMPr accident prevention program.



Process 4:  Micronutrient Formulation.  Aqua ammonia is transferred from the 30,000-gallon stationary storage tank to one of two blenders along with water and other ingredients.  The transfer of aqua ammonia to the blending process is conducted by Facility Process Operators in accordance with the PSM/RMPr accident prevention program



OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for each covered processes. The worst case scenario release assumed that all the contents in the largest single storage tank were released.  For covered processes 1 and 2, the largest vessel would be a 30,000-gallon storage tank containing anhydrous ammonia.  For Processes 3 and 4, the largest vessel would be a 30,000-gallon storage tank containing aqua ammonia.  The anhydrous ammonia release was modeled as if the ammonia tank was punctured on the side at the ground level. The resulting release of ammonia was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.  The anhydrous ammonia release assumes that the entire contents of the tank are released instantaneously into the containment.



The alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for Covered Process 1 assumes a transfer hose failure.  The alternative scenario for Covered Processes 2 assumes a rupture of a 3-inch transfer line.    The alternative scenario for Covered Process 3 assumes a transfer hose failure.  The alternative scenario for Covered Processes 4 assumes a rupture of a transfer line at a location where the transfer line is outside the containment.  Although these events are classified as alternative scen

arios, even an accident of these types are unlikely to occur due to the safety equipment (excess flow devices, check valves) and operating procedures that Helena uses to safeguard ammonia transfer Branch.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Branch Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility.  The Branch Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Branch Manager is responsible for assuring that Helena Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Maintenance, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits.  Note that PSM/RMP Program Document includes all elements of a Program 3 process for Processes 3 and 4 even though these two processes are Program 2 due to the concentration of aqua ammonia in the process.  This was done for the sake of management consistency for all the covered processes at the facility.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Helena's Huntington Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia Branch at the Huntington Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Huntington Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Huntington Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Huntington County LEPC.



NOTE: Sect
ions 4, 5, and 6 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Huntington Facility.
